talk.start.para: âI want to take the opportunity this evening to join a number of speakers in this parliament who are concerned about the axing of Behind the News. Since the ABC went to air at 8 p.m. in 1932, it has been committed to providing educational programs for children. I am sure many people not only in my community but all the way across this country have fond memories of learning from the young team at Behind the News as they showed us the world in a language that we could understand. But Behind the News is no longer to be part of children's education in this country.

speech.para: Whilst it is not appropriate for government to interfere in programming decisions taken by the ABC, the government must bear some responsibility for the financial pressure the ABC is under and subsequent decisions that the ABC has to take to cut programs. My office has been inundated by complaints from parents, teachers and kids about the axing of this popular program. I had the privilege of recently receiving a delegation from Pleasant Street Primary School, who handed me a petition from their colleagues in grades 5 and 6. The petition has already been tabled in parliament and the students have been very active in letting me know the importance with which they view Behind the News. Fifty-eight students signed the petition and, if time permits, I will read some of their names into Hansard at the end of my contribution.

I also received some 62 letters from the students of Haddon Primary School. The letters overwhelmingly spoke out against the cuts to funding to the ABC and the axing of Behind the News. Larissa wrote:

quote.para: I am writing to you because the program Behind the News is being cut off because of Government spending. Myself and 62 other year 5/6s in our school look forward to it every week.

speech.para: Another student, Jarrod, wrote:

quote.para: I heard on the news that the government are pulling the plug on BTN. I don't want them to because it is a great program for kids who like to know what is going on around the world. Some guardians don't like their kids watching the news that adults watch. In BTN it doesn't have swearing in it. In adult news they have swearing and blood and guts. I will be appreciative if they don't cancel it.

speech.para: Alanna wrote:

quote.para: I wish to express my concern about the cutting of BTN next year. I am very disappointed because I enjoy watching the show because I hardly get to watch the news. The Government should consider the cutting because our âEducationâ is at risk.

speech.para: Finally, another student wrote:

quote.para: If the government cancels BTN lots of Australian kids won't be aware of what is happening in this world.

speech.para: Perhaps, after all, that is what the government wants. The Howard government has mounted an unprecedented attack on the ABC, both through funding cuts and through a concerted campaign to stifle its independence. I will continue to work with schools, parents and teachers in fighting this issue.

As I have mentioned, I would like to include in Hansard some of the names of the 58 children at Pleasant Street Primary School who have petitioned me on this issue. They include Eleanor Sedgwick, Jessikah Wintle, Ross Ward, Bernadette Oliver, Emily McDonald, Mathew Eades, Helen Harrison, Sophie Macalister, Brooke Palmer, Nicky Barton, Eloise Hille, Tracey Stevens, Annie Sienesi, Helena Kazepis, Tom Nash, Allyson Hankin, Mostafa Alwan, Margaret Littlebales, Christine Christie and Matt Whitear.

Some of the students of Haddon Primary School have been very active in writing to me over this issue. They have also sent their 62 letters to the Prime Minister of Australia, letting him know very clearly that they do not want Behind the News cut. One letter states:

quote.para: I'm writing to you because I'm concerned about the government cancelling Behind the News. The teachers at Haddon Primary School have acknowledged that Behind the News is a good educational show and is an excellent learning program for kids. We would like you to inform the government about our concerns.

speech.para: Another letter states:

quote.para: I'm writing because Behind the News is going to be cancelled and 61 kids and I are very disappointed because of that. If the government with its spending cuts has decided to cancel Behind the News, there won't be any kids news on TV, plus BTN is part of a way that kids can understand better. It's like current affairs for us kids. I'm saying please don't cancel BTN.

speech.para: And I am certainly saying to the government that the ABC is a worthy institution in this country that has suffered enormously under the pressure of this government's funding cuts and also because of pressure in terms of its independence. This is what happens when governments cut funding to the ABC. News programs such as BTN are invaluable to our children's education and invaluable to the students at both Pleasant Street Primary School and Haddon Primary School. I certainly hope that the government reconsiders the way in which it behaves towards the ABC because our kids deserve BTN to be back on the air.

talk.start.para: âI rise to commend the government's decision to retain Point Nepean in public hands. I also wish to congratulate the many people involved in that decision, including the community reference group members, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, the parliamentary secretary and a range of environmental groupsâfrom Environment Victoria, to the VNPA, to the National Trustâand the many people of good faith on all sides who contributed to this outcome.

speech.para: Public land is not easy to retain as public land, as we see in Victoria, where Devilbend, Royal Park, Kew Cottages, Royal Showgrounds and the old Mornington High School site have all been scheduled for possible housing developments by the Victorian government. But despite what is occurring in Victoria, I want to return to the decision on Point Nepean because I believe it is an outstanding decision. What the decision that was announced on 25 August means is, firstly, that there will be no housing and, secondly, that there will be public ownership of the whole site by governments forever. In particular, the last 90 hectares will be owned by Parks Australia, which owns and manages Uluru National Park and Kakadu National Park on behalf of the people of Australia. There will be public access. We will preserve the heritage buildings and we will preserve the bush.

The only thing we have not successfully completed is attempting to unify the entire area. We attempted to do that and there were a series of barriers. Firstly, it should be known that in 1988 the then Victorian government led by John Cain paid $5 million to the Hawke government to purchase part 1 of the site at Point Nepean, comprising $4 million in a land swap and $1 million in cash. So the precedent was set. Despite the earlier payment, the federal government offered the land at Point Nepeanâ270 hectares of it, excluding Police Pointâto the Victorian government in 1999 for free. That offer was finally refused in March 2001 when Steve Bracks, the Victorian Premier, rejected the offer. Despite that rejection, on 8 September 2002 he offered to purchase it. He then reneged on that.

Nevertheless, we have preserved the land. The only issue on which there is any remaining disagreement is not the ownershipâbecause those conditions have been solved; it will be in public hands foreverâbut the use. Everybody agrees that the heritage buildings should be used and not left derelict. So the Commonwealth has announced a lease process for 50 years for education and related purposes. Those are the core elements. Yet what we heard last night from the member for Wills, who is someone I respect, was a departure from his normal style because he used hatred and he used parliament to attack members of the community and the environment movement, perhaps because he is not familiar with the issue. In that context, there are a series of questions which have to be answered.

The member for Wills made an accusation about me that it was somehow improper, as was reported in the Mornington Mail of 21 August, that I `had been working at the prime ministerial level and there was no doubt about the outcome'. That was true, but he neglected to mention one thingâthat the previous paragraph begins:

quote.para: Point Nepean and its beaches will end up in public hands. I have been working at prime ministerial level and I have no doubt about that outcome.

speech.para: Four days later, on 25 August, exactly that outcome was announced. That is what we were talking aboutâpreserving the beaches in public hands foreverâand the government made that decision four days later. The member for Wills also attacked the Treasurer, saying that the Treasurer had in some way indicated that `our preference for the site' was the Lord Mayor's camp. Those words are fabricated; they are made up. They appear at no point in the Treasurer's interview.

Finally, the member for Wills also attacked Environment Victoria because they had so-called access to the Commonwealth government. Environment Victoria were one of a number of groups which were extremely tough on the Commonwealth government. They were unrelentingly tough, and I applaud their work and I applaud the work of Eric Noel, who was part of their group. But they were also tough on the state government, and for that they are being punished. It is sad to see that groups are being punished for that.

At the same time, I note that the member for Wills and the state government are supporting a lease, a three-star hotel, a conference centre, a jetty and a restaurant. These are all understandable parts of a bid, but they do not need to be involved in activities which are beneath themâof attacking children's camps and tertiary institutions. These are actions which we hope they would not carry out. I hope we can achieve a better standard of debate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âNext Sunday will be the second anniversary of the collapse of Ansett. As everyone knows, the collapse of Ansett was a corporate disaster for this nation; in particular for the constituents of my electorate, the electorate of Burke, it has been a very trying time. The electorate of Burke is very close to Tullamarine airport. A large proportion of Ansett's employees worked in Melbourne and lived in and around my electorate. Indeed, in the town of Sunbury, where I liveâthe second largest community in the electorate of Burkeâmore than 1,000 families have been directly affected as a result of the collapse of that great national aviation icon, Ansett. So I rise tonight to mention that, because the issue has perhaps lost the profile that it had a year ago.

speech.para: I inform the House and those listening broadly that there is still a long way to go to redress the problems associated with this collapse, not the least of which is examining the way in which corporate directors operate and the way in which they receive bonuses, even after collapses occur, as we know took place with Ansett. However, my concern is about proper redress for Ansett workers. It is important for the House to understand that the workers received a redundancy entitlement of eight weeks; some have received a further five weeksâthat is, between eight and 13 weeks of redundancy entitlements for employees who in many cases were actually owed almost two years of such entitlements. There is also the issue of superannuation. Superannuation entitlements have not been paid in full to those Ansett workers, and that has to be resolved and resolved quickly. On behalf of those former Ansett workers, I rise to emphasise the point that the government must impress upon the administrators the need to finalise this matter.

It is important to acknowledge also that, beyond the lack of payment of their redundancy and superannuation entitlements, many of these former Ansett workers are now struggling to find permanent full-time employment. They are no different from any other Australians looking for full-time permanent work but I make the point that they not only have incurred a significant financial loss in not being in receipt of their full entitlementsâdespite the government flaunting its Ansett ticket taxâbut also are struggling to find permanent full-time work. There are not permanent full-time jobs in my regionâcertainly not enough for those employees to find sufficient employment to provide for their families and to pay their mortgages.

So in many cases what we have is loss of employment, failure to find replacement or adequate replacement of employment and, indeed, in numerous cases the loss of the family home. I know of many families that have sold their homes because of the loss of their employment. Indeed, there have been breakdowns of families; probably most critically and most distressing for those involved with Ansett, many families have broken down as a result of this corporate collapse. These are the social impacts of things like this happening. It is important that we do not forget the Ansett workers, that we do seek to redress the problems in relation to their full entitlements and, in the broader objective, that we look to an economy that can provide decent jobs for these families and other families that have suffered a similar plight.

talk.start.para: âOn a number of occasions I have come into this chamber to talk about ways in which the Queensland Labor government is short-changing the residents of the Gold Coast, and I am prompted to come into this chamber once again to highlight the way in which the Beattie Labor government continues to engage in a charade. It is a charade because the rhetoric simply does not match the action. The money does not match the action; the dollars that the Queensland Labor government would like the people of the Gold Coast to believe it puts into Gold Coast City simply fail to materialise.

speech.para: These are not just sweeping generalisations; a deal of substance and research has gone into what I am saying in the chamber this evening. I turn to an authoritative source. Before I make any allegations this evening, I should put on the record that I used the state infrastructure plan that was publicly released by the Beattie Labor government. What is very clear from this state infrastructure plan that was released for the period 200203 is that Gold Coast residents are being short-changed by a Brisbane-centric, Brisbane biased and Brisbane focused Beattie Labor government that clearly must not care to retain the seven seats that it currently has on the Gold Coast.

Recently I took the opportunity to highlight some of the inequitiesâinequities that arise with road and transport funding that the Beattie Labor government puts in for the Gold Coast versus funding that it puts in for Brisbane City. A demographer of some note, Alan Midwood, recently released a report that highlighted the way in which the Gold Coast and, more broadly, south-east Queensland were growing. Those who have listened to words in this chamber know that Gold Coast City has been the fastest growing city for the last 30 years and is projected to be the fastest growing city for the next 25 years. In consequence of this, there are some unique demands placed on transport infrastructure. Part of making sure that our roads do not become congested is, first and foremost, a commitment to public transport. So the question that can be asked is: what is the allocation by the Beattie Labor government for public transport for Brisbane compared with that for the Gold Coast?

I can highlight to all those in the chamber that the Beattie Labor government currently provides $6 million a year for surfside bus lines on the Gold Coast. Contrast that, though, with the allocation that the Beattie Labor government in Queensland makes to public transport in Brisbane. The Premier says that the Gold Coast deserves support because it is Queensland's second largest city, but the support is simply not there in reality. That $6 million compares and contrasts very starkly with the hundreds of millions of dollars that the Beattie Labor government puts into the Brisbane city rail network. It compares and contrasts with the millions of dollars that are put into buses, ferries and the associated infrastructure for the Brisbane City Council. How can $6 million possibly stack up against the hundreds of millions of dollars that this Brisbane biased, Brisbane focused Beattie Labor government puts into Brisbane City at the expense of its poorer cousins in Gold Coast City?

Another example of transport infrastructure deals with the road system. In terms of road and land corridor infrastructure funding, according to the state infrastructure plan that the Beattie Labor government put outâand I am very pleased to highlight this to the Houseâ$4 million is being allocated to Gold Coast City in the 2002-03 plan. I highlight for the benefit of the House that the Beattie Labor government will put $105 million towards the Tugun bypass in the second year of construction. So we will be generous and say it is $109 million. Compare and contrast that with $419.7 million for land and roads in Brisbane City. It is very clear that the Beattie Labor government want to build bus ways in Brisbane, build inner-city bypasses in Brisbane and put hundreds of millions of dollars into public transport in Brisbane, but they only want to put a paltry $10 million or so into land and public transport infrastructure in Gold Coast City. Gold Coast residents join with me in condemning the Queensland Labor government for their lack of action on the Gold Coast. It is high time the seven state Labor MPs did something to represent their city rather than simply sit there in silence.

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise to speak about an issue of ongoing concern for me, as the federal member representing Holt, and of ongoing concern to the City of Casey. That ongoing concern relates to the Howard government's attacks on families within my electorate and within the City of Casey. I want to touch upon some statistics that adumbrate the problem. The City of Casey has a population which is expected to eventually reach 300,000 people. Seventy per cent of that population will be under 40 years of age. On average, 80 families per week move into the City of Casey. That is the equivalent of over 7,000 new residents each year. Sixty per cent of households in the City of Casey include children. It has the highest population of preschoolers in Victoria. Of Casey's population, around 20,000 people are aged between zero and five yearsâthat is about 12 per centâand there are 3,400 children attending preschool. In an age breakdown, there are 41,185 children between the ages of zero and 12. There are a lot of young families in my area, obviously.

speech.para: What the Howard government is doing is attacking these families in three areas, and I am probably only going to have time to touch upon two of those tonight. One area is the review of the family day care program. Within my electorate of Holt, approximately 2,000 children are cared for through the City of Casey family day care program, at a cost to the federal government of about $800,000 per year. If the operational funding for this program is removed, the majority of the parents of these children simply will not be able to afford to continue to work. This issue is not only raised by me from a Labor Party perspective, it has been raised as a serious issue of concern by the City of Casey. It is a significant issue of concern, particularly given the number of young childrenâas I mentioned earlierâand young families that would be affected by cuts to this particular program.

This government has no understanding of the needs of Australians like Holt constituent Jennifer Tranter, who was happy for me to speak about this and use her name in this House tonight. Jennifer and her partner have two children: Hannah, aged four, and Blake, aged 18 months. Both Jennifer and her partner work full time. They value family day care as one of the most flexible forms of care. It can provide weekend care, before and after school care, 24-hour care and care for children with special needs. Particularly for Jennifer, family day care helps by taking Hannah to and from preschool. Jennifer said to me last Wednesday:

quote.para: If I could not send my kids to day care, I would not be able to go to work. With only my partner's income to live on, we would be in a worst case scenario and end up losing our house. Day care is just so important to us.

speech.para: Jennifer and her partner pay $200 per week for family day care and with a mortgage and a young family simply cannot afford the $400 per week that a childcare agency would require. For families like Jennifer's, the Howard government is simply proving itself to be out of touch. Jennifer continued:

I know many couples who are in the situation where one partner works days whilst the other works nights just so they can have the Australian dream of owning a house and giving their kids a good future.

speech.para: That is a very fine sentiment. The fact is that this attack on family day care through the broad care review will jeopardise the operational subsidy.

talk.start.para: âThe City of Casey are saying this, Member for Robertson. They believe that as a consequence of this review they will lose the $800,000. So how can you say, Member for Robertson, that the Howard government is favouring families when the City of Casey, which is an independent body, is effectively saying that the Howard government is going to strip that $800,000 operational subsidy from them, which would then jeopardise their ability to provide a service to 2,000 children? It is a very interesting situation.

speech.para: The other issue that continues to resonate in my electorate is the demand for a Medicare office within the City of Casey. The Fountaingate shopping centre is where it is proposed. Some time ago I tabled a 20,000-signature petition which called upon the government to put a Medicare office in the Fountaingate shopping centreâthis is a shopping centre that has 12 million movements through it per year. It has 38,000 children aged between one and 11 within its vicinity. It is the largest shopping centre in Australia that does not have a Medicare office. The families in that area are sick of being lied to by the government as to why there is not a Medicare office there. The fact is that these families deserve an office. They have, as I have said, sent a petition of over 20,000 signatures requesting that. They are sick of the Howard government's rhetoric. What they want are services, not untruths. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise to pay tribute to the rural fire service and the many volunteers in my electorate of Robertson. Whilst it may be just coming into spring and the bushfire season is not yet upon us, we all vividly remember the terrible fire risk, fire damage and the loss that occurred in the bushfires of last summer. My electorate of Robertson covers 785 square kilometres and much of that is made up of national parks, including the Bouddi National Park, 1,216 hectares; the Brisbane Water National Park, 11,455 hectares; the Popran National Park, 3,970 hectares; and the Dharug National Park, 14,850 hectares. You can see that a vast majority of my electorate is made up of national parks and natural bushland, and it is a huge fire risk.

speech.para: During the summer of last year, we suffered quite considerable bushfires in our area, like many parts of Australia. Of course, Canberra suffered horrific losses as well in the bushfires. In my electorate of Robertson, we had no property loss. There were many hundreds of hectares of bushland burnt out, but we suffered no property loss and, more importantly, no loss of life or injury. You can see that we are well protected from bushfires in my electorate. Again, I want to pay tribute to the many hundreds of volunteers in the rural fire service who have given many hundreds of hours of dedicated service to the people of the Central Coast and have protected our properties for many years. I know that they are already back-burning and preparing themselves for the coming bushfire season. Without these volunteers, I am sure that many properties and lives would be put at risk during the coming bushfire season. On behalf of all the constituents in Robertson, I want to thank these volunteers not only from the rural fire service but from the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the New South Wales Rural Fire Service, the SES, the coastal patrol and Gosford City Council as well. talk.start.para: âI want to use the few minutes available to talk about a looming crisis in Indigenous education in Australia. Often when we talk about numbers in this place, people use percentages and they can be misrepresented. The actual hard numberânot the percentageâof Indigenous Australians commencing training as teachers in Australian universities is falling. It was lower in 2002 than it was in 1997. Over the five years 1992 to 1997, the number of Indigenous Australians training as schoolteachers grew steadily. Since 1997, it has fallen by 33 per centâfrom more than 1,200 down to between 800 and 900.

speech.para: Why does this matter? You can see why it matters to a lot of individuals, but I want to talk about what it means for Australia and for Indigenous Australians in particular. There is no solution to the crisis in the different outcomes achieved by Indigenous schoolchildren compared to the rest of the Australian school population. Any solution must include increasing the numbers of Indigenous teachers. There are significant differences in debate in Australia about the package of measures that would best turn around the relative educational disadvantage of young Indigenous Australians. There are many elements to the problem. No-one can say this one thing is the silver bullet that will solve the problem. In rural and remote areas of Australia and also in our capital cities and major regional cities, none of the solutions that are proposed can succeed without an increasing number of Indigenous teachers.

History tells us that the pathway from disadvantage for families and communities is often through teaching and nursing careers. Those are the first careers that families that have had nobody in tertiary education before tend to choose. They use them as a bridge to further and broaden their social advancement. I think we have an impending crisis in Indigenous education and an expanding inequality in educational outcomes in our country. It needs a focused, targeted program to encourage, recruit and retain Indigenous Australians into training as schoolteachers in our universities, or the disadvantage that young Indigenous Australians feel now will be greater in the years to come.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 14 May 2003:

question.para: (1) How many motions has the Sydney Airport Community Forum (SACF) tabled in respect of: (a) the implementation of the Precision Runway Monitoring System; and (b) the sale of Sydney Airport before first solving Sydney Airport's aircraft noise problems.
(2) What action has he taken in response to each of these motions.
(3) How many of these motions has he honoured in spirit and action.
(4) What is the total number of questions on notice received by him on the same issues
(5) Is he able to demonstrate how public aspirations and the public interest, as expressed in these motions and questions on notice, have been acted upon inspirit and in deed; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) (a) Airservices conducted a comprehensive trial of the Precision Runway Monitoring (PRM) during the extensive public consultation including the SACF members before it was introduced.
(b) The Government announced its intentions concerning Sydney's future airport needs in December 2000.
(3) I have given due consideration to these motions when they were presented to me.
(4) The Honourable Member knows how many questions he has asked on these issues.
(5) The Government gives careful consideration to the issues that affect communities when it formulates its policy and makes its decisions on aviation issues.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 27 May 2003:

question.para: (1) Do the guidelines adopted by the Ministerial Committee on Government Communications require that at least 7.5% of the budget for all Commonwealth newspaper and radio advertising campaigns must be devoted to non-English newspapers and radio stations.

(2) How much has the Therapeutic Goods Administration spent to date on newspaper and radio advertising in relation to the recall of medicines produced by Pan Pharmaceuticals Limited and what proportion, if any, of this amount has been devoted to non-English newspapers and radio stations.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Under the Guidelines for Australian Government Information ActivitiesâPrinciples and Procedures (the Guidelines) issued in February 1995, there is a requirement that at least 7.5% of the campaign budget allocated to newspaper advertising must be devoted to non-English newspapers. Similarly, at least 7.5% of the campaign budget allocated to radio advertising must be devoted to non-English radio.

(2) To 6 June 2003, the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has spent $10,383,003.39 on newspaper notices setting out for the public the products manufactured by Pan Pharmaceuticals Limited subject to recall. There was no advertising on radio or in non-English newspapers.
The advertising placed by the TGA was in the nature of public notices and, as such, it was non-campaign advertising which is not subject to the Guidelines that apply to Government campaigns.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 June 2003:

question.para: (1) What proportion of freight movements in Australia is transported by rail.
(2) How does this compare with the proportion of freight movements transported by rail (a) 5 years ago and (b) 10 years ago.
(3) Is he able to confirm whether the proportion of freight movements in the United States transported by rail is 0.4 or some other proportion.
(4) What is the current level of Commonwealth financial support for (a) improvements in rail transport and (b) improvements in road transport per year.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr Anderson
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Based on the Bureau of Transport & Regional Economics' estimates, the proportion of freight movements by rail in Australia, defined in terms of net tonne-kilometres, was 34.6 per cent in 2001.
(2) The comparable proportion of freight movements by rail in Australia in 1996 was 33.4 per cent. In 1991, the proportion was 33.5 per cent.
(3) In the United States, the Association of American Railroads reports that rail's share of tonne-kilometres of domestic intercity traffic in 2001 was 41.7 per cent.

(4) (a) In terms of the 2003-04 Budget, the Government will provide $0.4 million to the Australian Transport Safety Bureau to establish a rail database and confidential reporting system. An equity injection of $143.4m is being held subject to the successful conclusion to negotiations with the NSW Government. The Government's policy reform in this regard will see additional investments in rail from various sources including the Australian Rail Track Corporation, the private sector and the NSW State Government. This will facilitate my announcement of $870m being spent on the interstate rail line in NSW and is subject to the successful conclusion of negotiations.

(4) (b) In terms of the 2003-04 Budget, the Government will provide a total of $1 762 million in road funding. This consists of $700 million for National Highways, $227 million for Roads of National Importance, $4 million for Land Transport Research, $45 million for the Black Spots programme, $20 million for the Federation Fund, $302 million for Roads to Recovery and $464 million in untied funding as Local Government Financial Assistance Grants identified for roads.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 11 August 2003:

question.para: (1) Who is providing advice and assistance to Afghanistan to develop its domestic labour laws.
(2) What steps has Australia taken to ensure a role for the International Labour Organisation in assisting Afghanistan.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The American Bar Association is currently working on draft domestic labour legislation for the Afghan Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs. The International Labour Organisation, which recently established a small office in Kabul, has offered to review the final draft legislation.

(2) None. However, the International Labour Organisation has applauded Australia's refurbishment of the Jangalak Refugee Repatriation and Training Centre in Kabul as the sort of initiative it is seeking to launch as a first step in building the capacity of unemployed Afghans.

subdebateinfo.title: Trade: Australia-United States Free Trade Agreement
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2196)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 11 August 2003:

question.para: (1) Has the Australian shipping industry been included in the discussions with the United States Government on the possible Australian United States Free Trade Agreement.
(2) Has he offered to make any changes to existing restrictions on foreign shipping operating in Australian waters.
(3) Has the United States sought changes to existing restrictions on foreign shipping operating in Australian waters.
(4) Can he say what effect any changes to existing restrictions on foreign shipping operating in Australian waters would have on the Australian shipping industry.
(5) Will he guarantee that cabotage will be excluded from the Australian United States Free Trade Agreement negotiations.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The discussions on the possible Australia United States Free Trade Agreement are being conducted by senior Australian and United States officials. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and other Commonwealth agencies have regular dialogue with industries that have indicated an interest in the negotiations, such as the shipbuilding industry.
(4) There are no changes anticipated to existing restrictions on foreign shipping in Australian waters, therefore there will be no effect on Australian shipping.

(5) The Free Trade Agreement negotiations with the United States are at the stage of sharing information and perspectives on policies that are of concern to either side, and commenting on initial offers of commitments. It is not possible to speculate on any requests the United States may make of Australia in relation to cabotage in the maritime transport sector. However, Australia would need to assess carefully any US request in light of the need to preserve the fundamental benefits of our licensing/permit requirements for coastal trades. There has been no indication that the United States will be seeking any change to Australian policy in this area.
